word.entryDescription: to stop a tiring activity for a while so that you feel better
word.entryExample: The doctor told me that I had to rest my arm for a week.

word.entryDescription: a place where you can go to have a meal
word.entryExample: Did you like the new restaurant?

word.entryDescription: a road sign that limits something (e.g. speed, entry, waiting, etc)
word.entryExample: 'No entry' restrictive signs are used in places such as one-way streets to prevent vehicles driving against the traffic.

word.entryDescription: what you find out or achieve by doing something
word.entryExample: They make a hypothesis to predict what the results will be.

word.entryDescription: to start doing something again (after stopping or being interrupted)
word.entryExample: We resumed our dinner after the phone call.

word.entryDescription: a person or business that sells goods to consumers
word.entryExample: With the new system retailers will only be able to buy soya beans from land already cleared.

word.entryDescription: to give or send something back
word.entryExample: My mum bought this for me. It's too big. Can I return it?

word.entryDescription: to use something which has already been used
word.entryExample: One way of moving towards sustainable living is to reuse plastic bottles.

word.entryDescription: (of secrets) to find or show something that was unknown or hidden
word.entryExample: He may be sent to prison for revealing secrets of his country.

word.entryDescription: a report giving somebody's opinion of a film, book, concert, etc
word.entryExample: His latest film received positive reviews.

word.entryDescription: to study something again, particularly to prepare for an exam
word.entryExample: Daniel is going to revise for the test.

word.entryDescription: the process of studying something again, often in preparation for a test or examination
word.entryExample: The exam was easy because I did a lot of revision.

word.entryDescription: able to be used again for different data
word.entryExample: I usually use a memory stick or a rewritable disc to back up my work.

word.entryDescription: to write something again in a different way in order to improve it or because there is some new information
word.entryExample: One of the exam tasks was to rewrite the given sentences in reported speech.

word.entryDescription: a very large heavy animal with thick grey skin and a horn on its head
word.entryExample: Can you see the rhino in the river under the tree?

word.entryDescription: (for words, lines of poetry, etc) to end with similar sounds
word.entryExample: Not all poems have to rhyme!

word.entryDescription: a repeated pattern of sounds, music, etc
word.entryExample: It's a difficult rhythm to dance to.

word.entryDescription: very small white grains which are boiled to make them soft enough to eat
word.entryExample: Rice is a popular food in Asia.

word.entryDescription: to travel on an animal, bicycle, motorbike, etc
word.entryExample: Have you ever ridden a motorbike?

word.entryDescription: to travel on a bicycle
word.entryExample: Can you ride a bike?

word.entryDescription: unreasonable or silly
word.entryExample: Don't be ridiculous! I'd never go out with him!

word.entryDescription: the sport or activity of riding a horse or a bike
word.entryExample: This story is about riding a horse.

word.entryDescription: not left
word.entryExample: Do you know where the sports centre is? Turn right at the hotel and it's on the left.

word.entryDescription: stiff and difficult to move or bend
word.entryExample: Metal is a very strong, rigid material.

word.entryDescription: a small piece of jewellery worn on the finger
word.entryExample: Is Emma wearing a ring?

word.entryDescription: to make a sound, characteristic of some metals when struck
word.entryExample: I was in the library when the alarm rang!

word.entryDescription: to telephone somebody again, for example to return a call they made to you or because you were not available when they telephoned you
word.entryExample: Henry rang, and he wants you to ring him back.

word.entryDescription: to telephone somebody
word.entryExample: End the phone call now and don't ring up again.

word.entryDescription: (of fruit and other plants) fully developed and ready to be eaten
word.entryExample: Those tomatoes aren't ripe yet.

word.entryDescription: to move upwards or increase
word.entryExample: The water level in the rivers starts to rise.

word.entryDescription: having a chance that something bad might happen
word.entryExample: If Janet had unplugged the hair-dryer, which she often leaves in the bathroom, it wouldn't have been so risky.

word.entryDescription: a particular action or set of actions usually performed on a special occasion or in a ceremony
word.entryExample: The priest went through his usual rituals and then the service ended.

word.entryDescription: a long area on which vehicles drive
word.entryExample: Walk quickly across the road.

word.entryDescription: cooked in the oven
word.entryExample: Do you like roast potatoes?

word.entryDescription: a person who steals from a place, often with threats and violence
word.entryExample: The robber forced his way into the bank and made the staff tell him where the money was.

word.entryDescription: the crime of stealing from a place or person, often using threats or violence
word.entryExample: The suspect was accused of robbery.

word.entryDescription: a machine that can do work by itself, often work that people do
word.entryExample: My parents gave me a toy robot for birthday yesterday.

word.entryDescription: a tall thin round vehicle with a pointed top used to go into space
word.entryExample: The Apollo 11 crew were carrying people from different countries in their rocket.

word.entryDescription: the character played by an actor
word.entryExample: The actors' masks came to symbolise the type of role they were playing.

word.entryDescription: a small round loaf of bread for one person
word.entryExample: I’d like a fried egg roll, please.

word.entryDescription: a film or book about relationships and love
word.entryExample: If I go to the cinema, I enjoy watching a good romance – I really like films about love and relationships.

word.entryDescription: relating to love or showing loving feelings
word.entryExample: I like watching romantic films.

word.entryDescription: an inside part of a building that has its own walls
word.entryExample: Is this the picture of your new room?

word.entryDescription: plural of 'rose' – a plant with small sharp parts on its stem and colourful flowers which smell nice
word.entryExample: It was a beautiful country cottage with its red roses around the front door and its pretty cottage garden.

word.entryDescription: shaped like a circle
word.entryExample: A football ball is round.

word.entryDescription: a chin in a round shape
word.entryExample: People with rounded chins are supportive, generous and sympathetic.

word.entryDescription: a way along which someone or something travels between places
word.entryExample: This is the right bus. The museum is on this route.

word.entryDescription: the order in which you usually do things
word.entryExample: What's your daily routine?

word.entryDescription: money that is paid to the author of a book, piece of music, etc. each time that it is sold or performed
word.entryExample: He decided that all royalties from his latest album will go to charity.

word.entryDescription: a thick rubber ring that fits around the outer edge of a wheel
word.entryExample: Some swings have double handgrips or a rubber tyre.
